etymons.meaning: to strip off, take off, divest

translations: The merchant grew old. He grew old, he advanced in years. His son up and looked at him, the son looked at him like so. He says, ‘Daddy!’ He says, ‘Huh?’ He says, ‘Daddy, your temples have turned white! Daddy, your teeth/this tooth of yours, this one of them has also gone away. Daddy, I want you to settle down, I shall handle the business in your place. I shall do it in your place’. (NI 217)

Infectum.turoyo: 1) bəṯṯərməd-daʕər m-i=ʕazime, saləq l-u=bayto, mədle d-šoləḥ i=ǧubb-ayḏe w-mʕalaq-la 192; 33/92 [MT]; an=noše d-kət-ne hawxa, ḥa me-raġlelə=šolaḥḥeDD 393/7;g-šəlḥinaṭarfe d=gaban d-ab=baluṭešoləḥgurze d-daqneg-noḥar-le k-šoləḥ u=gald-ayḏe
translations: ‘We tore off the branches, which were near us, of the durmast
‘He tore out a clump of hair (from) his beard’ 75/157;
‘He slaughtered him (lion cub, m.) and skinned him’ 75/311;

Infectum.turoyo: 2) i=fuǧo i=naqla d-məṭyoʕal u=kero; w d-nošolə=šolaḥ-la, məg-ǧore-la? 192; 77/24; 116/30; 3) kulyawmo ko-bode, w šoləḥparčaye m-d-u=baṣrayḏa 192; 60/332;

Infectum-wa.turoyo: 1) i=naql-ayo d-howe-wa u=qufloebe-ste...g-šoláḥ-way-no u=zənǧər-awoLB 156;i=naqla d-ubʕína-wo d-sŭḥéna-wo b-u=baḥar, šulḥína-wo ǧulayna b-u=bayto, w lŭšína-wo aǧ=ǧule d-u=baḥar, xədšarwolo, w faytína-wo, m-i=ǧaʕd-aṯe, w mḥalqína-wo ruḥayna b-u=baḥar 2/93; 3) d-l-ǝ́mmo-wahawxa, oʕdogə-mḥaláq-way-no u=sayfoʕalqarʕux w gə-šoláḥ-way-no qarʕux 192; 105/73;

Imperativ.turoyo: 1) šlaḥ u=sayfo w i=tfənge 192; prs 56/17; 44/92; i=aṯtoǧġəḷḷa i=ṣopa w-məḷḷe: “de šlaḥ i=qundraye!” ‘
translations: The wife stoked the stove and said: “Take off your shoes!”’ LB 258;

Infinitiv.turoyo: 3) d-obətdaṣṭərdiḏi g-əzzí tarte=kore s-i=ḥurm-aṯe d-lə=saymal-la hāšt b-u=šloḥo d-qarʕi! 192-193; 67/178;

Preterit.turoyo: Riḥān, asxammenelayt, qṭi-le ġắlabe w mšalaḥleġắlabeḥ 193; prs 116/28; i=naqladə-mšalḥənnedaʕirihúwwan-ne l-a=tfəngaṯṯetlallekīn b-lebayye 161; 71/20;

Infinitiv.turoyo: mʕalaqle u=sayfayḏe b-katfe w azzé l-ad=darbe d-an=noše l-u=šəloḥo 193; prs 132/36;
translations: sein Schwert um die Schulter und
